channel.title: 31st Annual Couchiching Conference, 1962
channel.description:
The 31st edition of an annual meeting held in Geneva Park, Ontario. Political matters are discussed, with an emphasis on how they relate to Canada. This edition focuses on "The New Europe."

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: A New Europe #1: A British view
item.description: William Clark, foreign affairs correspondent for The Observer, gives a British view of European progress since World War II and an examination of the reasons behind contemporary British negotiations. John Holmes introduces Clark and offers a Canadian perspective on developments in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: A New Europe #3: The cultural pattern
item.description: In the third session of the 1962 Couchiching Conference, William Clark, foreign affairs correspondent for The Observer, and Eric Peterson of the research department of the Confederation of Swedish trade unions, discuss the growing impact of automation and affluence on European society.
item.dc:creator: Grant, George Parkin, 1918-1988
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: A New Europe #2: Isms and atttitudes
item.description: This session features a speech by French philosopher, sociologist, political scientist, and journalist Raymond Aron, who focuses on the relationship between the loss, abandonment, or liberation of British, French, and Belgian empires and new prosperity of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: A New Europe #5
item.description: This program features a discussion of the potential impact of Great Britain joining the Common Market and includes remarks by economists William Diebold and Henry L. Munn.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: A New Europe #7: Europe and the modern world
item.description: This seventh and final session of the 1962 Couchiching Conference addressed two issues: Europe's place in a world where few peoples are rich and most are poor and don't seem to be getting much richer; and Europe's place in a world where everyone is threatened to some degree by the possible use and indeed the very existence of nuclear weapons. Panelists included British journalist and commentator William Clark, European intellectual Raymond Aron, and Canadian economic and political consultant Harry Wilson.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: A New Europe #4: Government, management, and labor
item.description: From the Canadian point of view and perhaps from the European point of view, in a great many successful businesses the government is a 50 percent partner. This session focuses on the interplay of government, management, and labor.
item.dc:creator: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: A New Europe #6
item.description: This session's topic is Eastern Europe and problems of East-West economic cooperation. It features a speech by Dr. Vladimir Velebit, the executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, as well as commentary by Dr. Raymond Aron of the Sorbonne.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics
